newsitem.title: NICARAGUA: Nicaragua's Sandinistas plan economic opposition.
newsitem.headline: Nicaragua's Sandinistas plan economic opposition.

text.p: Nicaragua's left-wing Sandinista Front is helping farmers and ranchers plan opposition to government economic policies that they say are crippling food producers, a top Sandinista said on Tuesday.

Sandinista congressman Victor Hugo Tinoco told reporters his party's leadership had held a series of meetings with unions, farmers and ranchers to organise opposition to the economic policies of President Arnoldo Aleman's right-wing government, which took power on Jan. 10.

"We think that the government's economic policies are wrong and producers have the right to demand changes in these economic policies," Hugo said. He said the Sandinistas, who governed Nicaragua from 1979 to 1990 with Cuban and Soviet backing, would have a policy statement ready in "a few weeks."
"The producers who see that they are going to continue to be inviable with these new policies, that producing in Nicaragua will not be profitable, are organising and mobilising," he said.

His comments came after a local newspaper reported the Sandinista leadership had planned a series of measures to protest the government's economic policy, including a 12-hour general strike to paralyse the capital Managua.
"We are studying measures that would oblige the government to make a commitment to the popular sectors," Hugo told the newspaper La Tribuna on Monday.
